captions.text:
This week, no residence
is safe, because you
are going to commit crime.

This episode of Scan
School brought to you
by Netflix and GoDaddy.

Warning-- the following episode
may contain eggs, gluten, soy
and crime.

Welcome to Scam School,
the only show dedicated

to social engineering at
the bar and on the street.
I'm your host Brian Brushwood,
And this week, I mean it.

We're back to hardcore
crime, because you

will go to jail if you have
used what you're about to learn.

Because we're about
to find out how

to use everyday objects
that you have in your house
right now to pick locks.
All right.

Finally, we get to learn
from a true expert.
Justin, how're you doing?
It's good to see you.

All right, so we
wanted to start off

by talking about
what kinds of locks
are easy to either pick or bump.

There's a bunch of different
ways to open locks, right?
Yes.

And what are the least safe
that people don't realize
aren't very secure at all.

Just about anything you can
buy in a hardware store,

Home Depot, any kind of
department-- anything
under $75.
{LAUGHS] Oh, really.
Yeah.

So pretty much
everybody watching,

their lock on the
front door at home
is easy to pick or bust into.
Right.

And you can have
an expensive lock,

but it could have an
inexpensive cylinder in it.
So don't be fooled by--
Explain to me that part.
Talk to me about the cylinder.

That's the center
part of the lock?

Yes, that's where
you put the key.

And that's what he
operates the bolt,
so you can lock and unlock it.

But you can have different brand
cylinders with high-end locks.

So you might have a
high-end, very fancy pants

secure lock, but
the cylinder's junk.
Right.

And then you could
just pop it right open.
Yeah.

Like for instance, Baldwin
is a very exclusive brand,
very expensive.

And you can have a very
inexpensive cylinder in there.
So the lock may be secure.

It might be a nice
lock, nice looking,

but it's still
very easy to open.

Now, I've done a little
bit of poking around,

and I learned one way to open
these locks, the one we're
going to talk about first.

But before we do, can
you give me an overview?

What are the different
ways that you
could get past a lot like this.

Well, there's
traditional picking,

like these kind of
pick pulls here,

which I'm sure everybody's
seen on James Bond.

TV, this pick gun
is very popular.
We can drill them.
Just drill it straight through?
Yeah, very easily.
You can bump key it.
OK.

And that's the one I learned
about was what the bump key.

So explain to me the principle,
because I kind of understand

and was able to
clumsily mess with it.

But what is the principle
of how a bump key works?
It's actually very simple.

You have these teams
keys, and the keys
will have spacing and depths.

This particular one
has six cuts on it.

And there'll be
zero to nine depths.

So from the top to the bottom is
spaced out in 1,500 increment.

And it'll be zero to
nine. [? Skip to 10. ?]

So what they do is they
cut all nines on there,
which is the deepest.

And these little
bumps, when you pull

it out about 1/16
of an inch and you

whack it with something,
applying slight turning

pressure, the tumblers all
get hit at the same time
and snap it.
So this is the lock.

Yeah, this is a
typical cylinder.

This would be the housing,
which up in the top chamber,
would be these strings.

And drivers, which
we call top pins.

And I guess all
of the brass part

here would be up
in the cylinder.
Be up inside this.

All of this silver
part would be-- what?
Down in here?

Inside the plug,
the cylinder plug.

And so it's only when
they're lined up just

like you see here, because
you can see on that key.

So you put the key in,
and it pushes all these--

It lines them up
perfectly even, which

creates what we call the sheer
line and allows it to turn.

And that's how different
combinations work.

So I guess when you put
in a normal key like this,

everything gets lined up, and
then it holds in that place.

And you could turn
it open like that.
Right.

But the difference
is with a bump key--

A bump key, what you're doing
is it's putting all the tumblers

on, which is dropping them
all below the sheer line.

And when you snap them
all simultaneously
it creates a gap.

It snaps the bottom to the
top pin and the spring.
And it will create a slight gap.
Just for a split second.
And it allows it to turn.
It's that's like playing polo.
You can hit the ball.

The band stands still and
the other ball goes flying.
It's the same principle.

So in this case, all of
these are getting hit

and it's transferred the
energy up and in the spring,

so all of these go
up, just long enough,

just for that
fraction of a second,
because they're spring loaded.

And if you hit it just
right, it'll break that gap.
Dude, that's unreal.
That's unreal.

And so we actually
have a faux door here.

I was going to give it a try,
and see if I could actually
pull off the bump key.
Sound good?
You got it.

Now, normally this is where
we continue our graduate level

course in Scamology
through the use of Netflix

by suggesting another
scam or con movie for you
to check out at home.

But this time I want
to turn the tables

and ask you guys what are
the movies I've missed.

What is the best con movie

Write me directly at

But meanwhile we

episode of Scam School.

and of course, remember

just as important as the

to make sure we get

So this is what we put together.

Actually my intern,

This is the actual

And then I went

all I did was Google "bump key,"

Now, this is what surprised me.

Mailbox.

So you can bump master

Theoretically.
OK, interesting.
I'll ask you more about that.

Not all locks are going
to be as easy as others,

but it's possible with
a little bit of practice
you might get them.
OK.
Interesting.

And this one looks like
those ones that always say

commercialized institutions.
Right.

That looks like a

key, which, you know,
got to give it a shot.
It's possible.

[LAUGHS] Well, speaking

This is the actual

OK, so I guess there's

And so like this one doesn't

And the way I

And then you just give

You don't want to push it too

But if you just barely

and then give it a whack,

Yeah, you're pushing it back in.

And that's snapping all

And that will create the bump.

I guess this is not the

And so this is a

And I was shocked.

I thought for sure,

And again, I got to give

It's a really light touch.
Yeah, it's very light.

If you give it too much

So it's almost like
a timing issue.

You have to give it

How hard should
you need to hit it.
You get a good even--
Oh, there we go!

Home version works,

Now the thing is that each

But you were saying there's a

Well, sometimes you could use

Now is this any kind of

Any old ring that you

And I guess the

Right.

So in this case, you

Oh, that's so much easier!

Because when you have

You still have to twist

That is scary-easy.

The advantage is
you can manipulate
the turning pressure easier.

OK, because you're not trying to
do a timing thing or anything.

No, you're not trying

You're just working
on concentrating
on how much pressure you give.
Now turn it.

So it really is all in

It's all in the turning.

Well.

Of course.
So--

OK?

Right, so assuming this is

is take a file and
file them all down

the beginning of the milling.
What kind of file do we want?
You'd want to use a round file.

And what's really

The positioning, the--

If the spacing is off,

comments.author: Edward Ratliff

comments.text:
Theres also factor that causes problems to make it look this easy. If the 
lockmechanism (the part which goes inside the door frame) is even a bit 
stuck at the frame (normally the sealing rubbers that makes the door not 
venting the air around it) and you have to push or pull the door to turn 
the key, maykes it harder to use this method. Older door frames may need 
some lifting to make slide snap open easily, because the hinges may be 
worn, and the door is resting on the frame from down part a bit.﻿
comments.author: Randomnick123

comments.text: +Randomnick123 good points.
comments.author: Scam School

comments.text:

all the criticizing on here for No reason when movies show you the exact 
same thing!﻿

comments.author: Scam School

comments.text:
+zatanzilla This is one of the more infuriating complaints people have 
about these videos, it's just such a pedantic point. Know that you aren't 
the first to make it, which is why it's worth giving thought. You can see 
how long the video is before you watch it, I can't imagine it's that 
surprising to discover. The title isn't saying "This video that is only a 
few seconds long will teach you how to open a lock," it's implying "once 
you've seen this video, you will know a method to opening locks that only 
takes a few seconds."

I guess you might think this would be a 5 second video of a guy bumping a 
lock and that's it, but what would anybody learn from that? You develop 
skills by understanding how the mechanics work and teaching that takes time.

comments.text:
It does suck that lock makers have known of this design flaw since the 
Mesopotamian days and continue to replicate it. If they would put a small 
piece of wick into each spring they won't bounce. Isn't it comforting how 
simple it is, just one slight tick with a nylon tapper and yer open. You 
were hitting it too hard and using the wrong tapper. I'll give you credit 
for not using a hammer. ;) 
  People need to light a fire under lock manufacturers asses to get them to 
fix this design flaw. It's so easy a child can do it.  :(﻿

+1.618033 there's a great episode of 99% Invisible about this exact stuff: 
http://99percentinvisible.org/episode/perfect-security/

comments.author: Scam School

comments.text:
The video should probably point out that possession of lock picks or a bump 
key is a crime by itself in many states, and if a person is caught 
committing a crime with lock picks in their possession, the crime could 
potentially be bumped up to a felony. Generally there's some wording of 
'intent' but if you're caught trespassing, that might serve as intent. 
Making these for or loaning them to a friend can also be a crime. Like the 
video says, play with em at home if you want, but not elsewhere, and don't 
carry any potential 'burglar tools' around on you. ﻿
